Intersession to be retained in present form
By )OE BUSCEMA
At its April 24 meeting, the
Academic Council accepted the
recommendation of the Council
on Undergraduate Studies to
retain the intersession program in
its present grade-credit form for
an additional two years.
A proposal by the CUS on the
subject of Freshman first
semester pass/fail policy was also
approved. Under the
modification to the existing
pass/fail policy, institutions must
request in writing the grade for a
specific course entered on a
transcript in coded form. With
student approval, the specific
grade will be released to the
requesting school.
"The issue of doing away with
grades and credit for intersession
courses was discussed before the
Council on Wednesday," said Dr.
George Owen, Dean of Arts and

Sciences.
"The General Assembly,
serving in an advisory capacity to
the Academic Council, made the
recommendation to eliminate
credit and grades on the basis of
a 26-24 vote," Owen pointed
out.
"However, the Council
accepted the advice of the CUSt
in voting unanimously to
continue intersession, unchanged,
for another two years." he
added.
The major factor behind the
CUS recommendation to
maintain intersession in its
present form is the unwavering
interest displayed by students for
the past two years, according to
Sigmund Suskind, Dean of
Academic Programs.
"The Office of the Registrar
has provided information based
on course offerings and

enrollment during intersession,
indicating that student
participation is going up as are
the number of courses being
offered," said Suskind. "The
majority of intersession courses,
perhaps 90 percent or more, are
taught for credit."
"The general feeling with
respect to intersession, given its
limitations and lack of structure, is that people are happy with it,"
he commented.
"As long as no rules are
established making attendance by
students mandatory, there will be
no rule forcing faculty
participation," he said. "The
system will continue to work on
a voluntary basis, with options
open to the faculty and
students."
"I see it as a nice informal way
of spending three weeks," he
added.

like Thomas Mann..Not his style I mean, but

Thomas Mann and I have

Once when I was a little kid I
asked my father what the point of it all was.
We were walking hand in hand across one of
the University athletic fields. Big people were
playing softball and their girls were in the
bleachers rooting them on.
'One day, Thomas, you'll be
dead' he said. 'Everyone must die. Its

My mother had a different

nice things she was always saying.
